Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: Multi-level predictive analytics & motif discovery across massive dynamic spatio-temporal networks in complex socio-technical systems: An organizational genetics appro

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Our lives are becoming increasingly connected with Big Data. Massive amounts of digital trace data are being generated from the activities and events of complex socio-technical systems consisting of human actors and man-made artifacts (which refer to as social objects). Such complexity comes from the massively interconnected and computed nature of the contemporary digital world. These data sets are different from traditional data as they are typically massive, unstructured, granular, heterogeneous, dynamic, and performative. Using Big Data, the researchers are able to understand and predict behaviors of complex socio-technical systems. To support such efforts, the researchers will build a new methodological framework based on an evolutionary ontology that treats variation as real and as the fuel of evolution. Specifically, the researchers analyze data set from Twitter (one of the largest social media sites) and Github (the largest open source community) to test and validate their framework. As the role of Big Data continues to increase in our society, the researchers plan to develop online curricula to help students learn how to access, manage, analyze, and visualize big data sets via a variety of approaches.

The researchers are developing a method to predict the emergence of system-level behaviors by analyzing large volumes of digital trace data using evolutionary social ontology to build a multi-level model of complex socio-technical systems. They use analytical techniques developed in evolutionary biology and systems biology: (1) to characterize a stream of digital trace data from a complex socio-technical system with finite genetic elements; (2) to predict the behavior of socio-technical systems based on the pattern of "behavioral gene" interactions; and (3) to explore the impact of mutational input, gene flow, and recombination in "behavioral genes" on the evolution of socio-technical systems. The researchers test their model in GitHub, one of the largest open source communities that includes over 5 million open source software development projects and Twitter, one of the largest social media site, that has over 500 million messages per day. The model generated from this research can be used for other types of massive digital trace data including sensor data from Internet of the Things and mobile data from smartphones.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our lives are becoming increasingly connected with Big Data. Massive amounts of digital trace data are being generated from the activities and events of complex socio-technical systems consisting of human actors and man-made artifacts (which we refer to as social objects). Such complexity comes from the massively interconnected and computed nature of the contemporary digital world. These data sets are different from traditional data as they are typically massive, unstructured, granular, heterogeneous, dynamic, and performative. Using Big Data, we are able to understand and predict behaviors of complex socio-technical systems. In this project, we built a new methodological framework based on an evolutionary ontology that treats variation as real and as the fuel of evolution. Toward this goal, we developed a method to predict the emergence of system-level behaviors by analyzing large volumes of digital trace data using evolutionary social ontology to build a multi-level model of complex socio-technical systems. We use analytical techniques developed in evolutionary biology and systems biology: (1) to characterize a stream of digital trace data from a complex socio-technical system with finite genetic elements; (2) to predict the behavior of socio- technical systems based on the pattern of ?behavioral gene? interactions; and (3) to explore the impact of mutational input, gene flow, and recombination in ?behavioral genes? on the evolution of socio-technical systems. We test our model in GitHub, one of the largest open source communities that include over 5 million open source software development projects. Our data includes all time-stamped 14-different types of events from 178,558 projects from JavaScript community (N=170,057) and R community (N=8,501). The data covers a 30-month period from 1/1/2015 to 6/30/2017. The total number of events from JavaScript community includes 9,653,486 and 244,256 for R community. These actions were taken by 2,982,793 unique developers in JavaScript and 32,520 for R. Based on the empirical study, we have also built a simulation model to predict the evolution of organization routines over time. 

We also applied our analytical framework to build a predictive model for the success and failure of digital prodcts in digital platform ecosystems. Our data entails 8,392 R packages developed by 11,830 developers. We found that packages that use of exogenous codebases, particularly those that lead to structural changes in the ecosystem, contributes to the success of the packages. We also found that packages that combine exogenous codebases from multiple clusters in the ecosystem are more popular. The work has been submitted to Research Policy, a top research journal in management.

The final framework is forthcoming in the Journal of Association of Information Systems. To illustrate the power of our framework, we analyzed the success and failure of Wikipedia documents, using a sample data set collected from 8144 English Wikipedia (4144 are featured articles, and 4000 are non- featured articles) over 30 different topics.

In addition, we organized a research workshop on "Big Data and Digital Innovation" on October 18-20, 2018. The outcome from the workshop is published as the Handbook of Digital Innovation. 

Finally, we created a website, PlayBigData (http://playbigdata.org) which provides an easy-to-follow instructions of our framework and illustrative examples from our own research for the general public who are interested in learning how to use large-scale digital trace data. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 04/28/2021
Modified by: Youngjin Yoo
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Our lives are becoming increasingly connected with Big Data. Massive amounts of digital trace data are being generated from the activities and events of complex socio-technical systems consisting of human actors and man-made artifacts (which we refer to as social objects). Such complexity comes from the massively interconnected and computed nature of the contemporary digital world. These data sets are different from traditional data as they are typically massive, unstructured, granular, heterogeneous, dynamic, and performative. Using Big Data, we are able to understand and predict behaviors of complex socio-technical systems. In this project, we built a new methodological framework based on an evolutionary ontology that treats variation as real and as the fuel of evolution. Toward this goal, we developed a method to predict the emergence of system-level behaviors by analyzing large volumes of digital trace data using evolutionary social ontology to build a multi-level model of complex socio-technical systems. We use analytical techniques developed in evolutionary biology and systems biology: (1) to characterize a stream of digital trace data from a complex socio-technical system with finite genetic elements; (2) to predict the behavior of socio- technical systems based on the pattern of ?behavioral gene? interactions; and (3) to explore the impact of mutational input, gene flow, and recombination in ?behavioral genes? on the evolution of socio-technical systems. We test our model in GitHub, one of the largest open source communities that include over 5 million open source software development projects. Our data includes all time-stamped 14-different types of events from 178,558 projects from JavaScript community (N=170,057) and R community (N=8,501). The data covers a 30-month period from 1/1/2015 to 6/30/2017. The total number of events from JavaScript community includes 9,653,486 and 244,256 for R community. These actions were taken by 2,982,793 unique developers in JavaScript and 32,520 for R. Based on the empirical study, we have also built a simulation model to predict the evolution of organization routines over time. We also applied our analytical framework to build a predictive model for the success and failure of digital prodcts in digital platform ecosystems. Our data entails 8,392 R packages developed by 11,830 developers. We found that packages that use of exogenous codebases, particularly those that lead to structural changes in the ecosystem, contributes to the success of the packages. We also found that packages that combine exogenous codebases from multiple clusters in the ecosystem are more popular. The work has been submitted to Research Policy, a top research journal in management. The final framework is forthcoming in the Journal of Association of Information Systems. To illustrate the power of our framework, we analyzed the success and failure of Wikipedia documents, using a sample data set collected from 8144 English Wikipedia (4144 are featured articles, and 4000 are non- featured articles) over 30 different topics. In addition, we organized a research workshop on "Big Data and Digital Innovation" on October 18-20, 2018. The outcome from the workshop is published as the Handbook of Digital Innovation. Finally, we created a website, PlayBigData (http://playbigdata.org) which provides an easy-to-follow instructions of our framework and illustrative examples from our own research for the general public who are interested in learning how to use large-scale digital trace data.
